sections.title: AHA Accredited
sections.subtitle: This protocol follows American Heart Association Basic Life Support choking guidelines with AI safety guidance.

steps.title: Assess the situation
steps.subtitle: Ask 'Are you choking?' If they cannot speak, cough, or breathe, they need immediate help.

steps.title: Position Adult
steps.subtitle: Stand behind person. If seated, have them lean forward.

steps.title: Give Back Blows
steps.subtitle: Stand behind them, lean them forward, and give 5 sharp blows between the shoulder blades.

steps.title: Perform Heimlich Maneuver
steps.subtitle: Place hands above navel, thrust inward and upward 5 times. Alternate with back blows.

steps.title: Call for Help
steps.subtitle: If object doesn't come out after several attempts, call 911 while continuing efforts.

steps.title: Assess the Situation
steps.subtitle: Ask: “Are you choking?” Check if child cannot speak, cough, or breathe effectively.

steps.title: Position Child
steps.subtitle: Stand behind child or have them lean forward. Support chest with one hand.

steps.title: Give Back Blows
steps.subtitle: Give 5 sharp back blows between shoulder blades with heel of hand.

steps.title: Abdominal Thrusts (Child)
steps.subtitle: Place hands above navel, thrust inward and upward 5 times with less force than adult.

steps.title: Call for Help
steps.subtitle: If object doesn’t come out after several attempts, call 911 while continuing efforts.

steps.title: Assess the Situation
steps.subtitle: Check if infant is conscious and unable to cry or make sounds. Look for signs of distress.

steps.title: Position Infant
steps.subtitle: Place infant face-down on your forearm, supporting head and neck. Keep head lower than chest.

steps.title: Back Blows for Infant
steps.subtitle: Give 5 firm back blows between shoulder blades using heel of hand.

steps.title: Chest Thrusts
steps.subtitle: Turn infant over, give 5 chest thrusts with 2 fingers on breastbone.

steps.title: Call for Help
steps.subtitle: If object doesn’t come out after several attempts, call 911 while continuing efforts.
